Alex T. Archibald, Yusuf Hamied
Department of Chemistry
University of Cambridge
Cambridge, UK, CB2 1EW

Abstract
Surface ozone is a significant air pollutant that contributes to hundreds of thousands of premature deaths annually. Accurate short-term ozone forecasts can help reduce the risk to health through air quality warnings. However, forecasting ozone is a challenging task due to the complex interactions of physical and chemical processes that occur on various timescales. To improve forecasting accuracy, we employ a state-of-the-art transformer-based model, the Temporal Fusion Transformer, trained on observational data from three European countries.

In four-day test forecasts of daily maximum 8-hour ozone, the novel approach demonstrates high skill (MAE = 4.6 ppb, R2 = 0.82) and generalizes well to two European countries not seen during training (MAE = 4.9 ppb, R2 = 0.79). The model outperforms standard machine learning models and compares favorably to published performance of other deep learning architectures on different data. We show that the model focuses on physical variables known to control ozone concentrations and uses relevant past ozone concentrations to make accurate forecasts.

1 Introduction
Surface ozone is a secondary pollutant formed in the troposphere through photochemical reactions. It is estimated to contribute to between 365,000 and 1.1 million premature deaths worldwide annually, primarily due to cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. The impacts of ozone pollution have been linked to both long- and short-term exposure to high ozone levels. Background ozone levels in remote areas often exceed guidelines, while local concentrations can far exceed guidelines. The World Health Organization estimates that 99% of the world's population lives in areas where concentrations routinely exceed guidelines.

Due to its phytotoxicity, ozone air pollution has significant negative effects on vegetation, ecosystems, and crops, leading to considerable economic losses from reduced crop yields. Forecasting ozone concentrations is essential to quantify and reduce the risks of ozone pollution to human and ecosystem health, particularly as climate change is expected to lead to increased ozone in some regions.

Derived from the key processes controlling ozone, in-situ photochemical production and transport, there are multiple relationships between ozone and climate-sensitive environmental covariates such as temperature and meteorology that act on varying timescales. The contribution of each of these factors makes accurate forecasting of ozone with numerical forward transport models and standard machine learning methods a complex and computationally expensive task.

Transformers have been shown to be highly effective in sequential domains such as natural language processing, in part due to their ability to attend to long-term dependencies in the data. Therefore, a transformer-based model may provide an intrinsic advantage over standard machine learning models and convolutional and recurrent neural networks that have been previously explored in the ozone forecasting literature.

In this work, we train and evaluate a transformer-based model, focusing on the skill of the model when forecasting extreme ozone and ozone in countries unseen during training. This is a step towards machine learning models capable of making accurate short-term forecasts of surface ozone now and in future climates.

2 Methodology
2.1 Model
To complement existing machine learning methods and numerical models for ozone forecasting, we deploy a state-of-the-art temporal deep learning architecture, the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT). The TFT combines gated residual networks, variable selection networks, a Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) encoder-decoder layer, and multi-head attention. The TFT ingests both static and dynamic predictive features, and a quantile loss function is used to extract prediction intervals.

Training the TFT on our dataset took 2 hours using 2 Tesla V100 GPUs. Once trained, forecasts across 994 individual stations are made in seconds, illustrating the vast speed-up of machine learning models compared to numerical models (which typically take hours or days to run). Hyperparameters were manually optimized for performance on validation data (see Appendix A).
